com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

com:
Why the fuck does the American legal system so often seem to duplicate charges so often?

Specifically when I hear people being charged with the exact same crime twice, because it involves something that technically exists across more than one states (e.g. robbing a bank gets you charged with multiple felonies simply because banks are national entities with insurance across state lines)

This just seems far too punishing with not enough logic behind it. Most countries as far as I can tell only charge you with a crime once, or possibly multiple times only if it’s a crime that was committed across multiple NATIONS. Even then that’s pretty rare.

How did America end up with a legal system with this quirk? Seems like it would make more sense to just have the charge be either entirely localised to a state, or have it be entirely based around federal crimes, with either option being based on the specific crime. Not the weird mish mash of both

last_replies.com:
>>14291553
The American criminal law system actually doesn't do this as much as it might seem. Nearly all crimes are handled by the states. The portfolio of what the federal government can legislate on is limited by article 1 of the constitution, and so is mostly related to interstate financial crimes, crimes directly against the us government, and other interstate crimes like smuggling. But the federal criminal docket is quite small compared to that of the states.

>How did America end up with a legal system with this quirk
It's called federalism, and it's something we've had since our founding. In 1789 when our constitution was ratified, each state already had well developed judiciaries, with their own laws and traditions that differed from one another, sometimes quite significantly. So partly not wanting to change that, and partly out of a desire to avoid making the federal government too powerful, it was decided to create a two tiered court system with separate state and federal courts. In 1868, right after the civil war, the constitution was changed so that something called the due process clause applied to the states. Essentially this gave the federal government more power to declare state laws or court decisions unconstitutional, and we have something called the supremacy clause, which means when a federal and state law say opposite things about the same issue, the federal law will control. But the existing federalist framework was never abandoned, and this allows different states to have very different laws if that's what the people of that state want.

By the way, if you think this is convoluted, you should see how we handle civil cases. In some situations you can sue someone for a state law claim in a federal court, and have them apply the laws of a completely different state from the one it's in. That actually happens all the time.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14291701
>and we have something called the supremacy clause, which means when a federal and state law say opposite things about the same issue, the federal law will control

Actually what the supremacy clause means is:

>The Federal government has a certain list of enumerated powers
>he states shall not interfere in the Federal government's execution of its lawfully enumerated powers

Furthermore in Prinz v. United States, the Supreme Court ruled that states are not required to enforce nor assist in the enforcement of Federal laws, just that the supremacy clause means states cannot interfere with Federal authorities in the act of enforcing them. As we have seen now many states have legalized marijuana although a Federal prohibition on it still exists.

>Western Steppe Herders are considered descended from Eastern Hunter-Gatherers (EHGs) who reproduced with Caucasus Hunter-Gatherers (CHGs), and the WSH component is analysed as an admixture of EHG and CHG ancestral components in roughly equal proportions, with the majority of the Y-DNA haplogroup contribution from EHG males. The Y-DNA haplogroups of Western Steppe Herder males are not uniform, with the Yamnaya culture individuals mainly belonging to R1b-Z2103 with a minority of I2a2, the earlier Khvalynsk culture also with mainly R1b but also some R1a, Q1a, J, and I2a2, and the later, high WSH ancestry Corded Ware culture individuals mainly belonging to haplogroup R1b in the earliest samples, with R1a-M417 becoming predominant over time.

Around 3,000 BC, people of the Yamnaya culture or a closely related group, who had high levels of WSH ancestry with some 10-18% Early European Farmer (EEF) admixture, embarked on a massive expansion throughout Eurasia, which is considered to be associated with the dispersal of at least some of the Indo-European languages by most contemporary linguists, archaeologists, and geneticists. WSH ancestry from this period is often referred to as Steppe Early and Middle Bronze Age (Steppe EMBA) ancestry.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14291665
This migration is linked to the origin of both the Corded Ware culture, whose members were of about 75% WSH ancestry, and the Bell Beaker ("Eastern group"), who were around 50% WSH ancestry, though the exact relationships between these groups remains uncertain. The expansion of WSHs resulted in the virtual disappearance of the Y-DNA of Early European Farmers (EEFs) from the European gene pool, significantly altering the cultural and genetic landscape of Europe. During the Bronze Age, Corded Ware people with admixture from Central Europe remigrated onto the steppe, forming the Sintashta culture and a type of WSH ancestry often referred to as Steppe Middle and Late Bronze Age (Steppe MLBA) or Sintashta-Related ancestry. Through the Andronovo culture and Srubnaya culture, Steppe MLBA was carried into Central Asia and South Asia along with Indo-Iranian languages, leaving a long-lasting cultural and genetic legacy.

The modern population of Europe can largely be modeled as a mixture of WHG (Western Hunter-Gatherer), EEF and WSH. In Europe, WSH ancestry peaks among Norwegians (ca. 50%) according to Haak et al. (2015), while in South Asia it peaks among the Kalash people (ca. 50%) according to Lazaridis et al. (2016). Narasimhan et al. (2019), however found it at a lower level (ca. 30%) among the Kalash.

com: Is stoning good or bad?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14290121
It's the most just form of punishment for major crimes and absolutely 100% certified halal.

1. It's a painful form of the death penalty. This makes it a better deterrence than most forms of execution.
2. It's cheap and easy to implement. You don't need exotic chemicals for a lethal injection. You don't need a sharp sword and a skilled executioner for a beheading. You don't need to house a person for 50 years in life imprisonment. All you need is some rocks.
3. It's public and communal. The whole community witnesses the execution, which serves as a warning for potential criminals. Even better, the viewers partake in the killing themselves. This leads to them internalizing the law even more strongly. Compare this with simply viewing a beheading, where the audience might identify with the victim since they are both passive. But in a stoning, there's a strong demarcation into us (the law-abiding citizens throwing rocks) and them (the condemned criminals being pelted).

People often view stoning disfavorably because they see it as a form of lynching, i.e. getting around due process. But that's a problem with lynching, not with stoning. As long as the condemned is given due process, there is no problem.

name: Anonymous
com:
Roughly the same amount of time has passed between the Vietnam War and today as passed between the American Civil War and the start of the 1920s. But when I look back on the Vietnam War era, even though I wasn't alive back then, the world at that time seems mostly recognisable to me. Some advancements have been made, the biggest probably being the internet, and there's been a pretty big shift in values and demographics, but generally it feels like people back then lived in a society similar to our own, at least technologically.

But when I think of the 1920s and compare it to the time of the American Civil War, they feel like two different worlds. Again the 1920s feel relatively modern, they had electricity, broadcasting, flight, cars, films, audio records, telephones, modern-ish guns, etc. By contrast the 1860s almost seem closer to the 1600s. People still used horses to get around, cavalry was still important in warfare, soldiers still fought by lining up in columns, marching forward in brightly coloured uniforms and firing single-shot weapons at each other.

It made me wonder, did people in the 1920s feel more distant from the 1860s than we do from the 1960s? Has the rate of technological progress slowed, or was it just unusually rapid back in the early 20th century?

com:
The "Red Summer" of 1919 was plagued by major violence and racial tensions across the United States. On September 30, two black men, one a WWI veteran, met their fate in Montgomery, Alabama, deep in the heart of the Jim Crow South. Robert Croskey, recently discharged from the Army, and Retious Phifer, were charged with assaults on white women. When word went out that a lynch mob was forming, a civilian got on the phone with Governor Thomas Kilby, who ordered the prisoners transfered to Wetumpka State Prison for safekeeping. However while they were being transferred, the mob caught the police vehicle carrying them. Both Croskey and Phifer were seized and riddled with bullets.

Around midnight on the same day, a police officer named James Barbaree arrested three blacks, two men and one woman, for a public street brawl. One of them, John Temple, escaped custody and ran. Officer Barbaree and Temple exchanged gunshots. Barbaree was hit, but managed to return fire. Temple was shot as well. Both men were mortally wounded and died within a few hours.

In Elaine, Arkansas, nearly 300 miles from Montgomery, September 30 also witnessed the Elaine Massacre in which black sharecroppers attempting to organize a union were the victim of massacres by white farmers. US Army troops were brought in to restore order during the three days of destruction. Estimates vary from 100 to over 230 blacks killed or injured, some possibly by Army troops. The white mobs did not spare women and children either. No whites were ever prosecuted for the massacre, but 122 blacks were charged with rioting, murder, and insurrection with 22 receiving the death sentence.

com:
The American Civil War wasn't about federalism vs state's rights or abolition vs slavery, it was about urbanism vs ruralism. Immigrants or the direct sons of Immigrants made up half the Union army and were mainly the ones who destroyed the majority WASPy Confederates along with what remained of their antiquated plantation-centric culture. For the Yankee, who was growing more detached from his Anglo Scots-Irish roots with each generation and each new wave of immigration, there was only one real problem with slavery - it kept urbanism, the natural abode of the new Germanic, Nordic, and Mediterranean Americans from spreading to its fullest across North America. Slave plantations couldn’t coexist with factories not because of cultural friction or even moral differences, but because the plantation by necessity kept the industrial labor-hungry immigrant or immigrant's son from getting what his family came to the US for in the first place: decebt jobs in an increasingly urbanizing and prosperous new country. The idea that the Union they crossed an ocean to be a part of would be torn apart by a minority of rural planters shackled to some archaic cotton-based economy in its death throes was simply unthinkable.

Union generals may have been mostly WASPs, but the soldiers they led were as muttified by 19th century standards as modern Ameimutts are now.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14290010
However, you also had smaller northern farmers across the Midwest and the plains who feared being outcompeted by cheap Southern slave labor. Do not discount their part in things - especially given that pretty large chunks of the regions I describe were also experiencing a great deal of immigration. In particular, I point to my maternal grandmother's side of my own family - of German descent, yet having established themselves as small-time farmers in rural Wisconsin. As well as my maternal grandfather's side of the family, of English descent, but also farmers within the same region - at least one of whom did fight for the Union. Not for urbanism, obviously.

Also: you mistake the plantation farming/industrial cities dynamic as a divide, when they are parts of a greater system. One produces raw materials, the other produces finished goods. They feed, or fed, into each other.

>Guess i will grow shitty wheat crops when there are better options

This is a misconception.
Grains/Cereal crops already existed in the wild in fields you could forage from. It's a grass. Their corns were tiny, but they were still a source of food come the autumn and would be plentiful in places normally vacant of other excellent forage.

>I will grind down the grain seed from the wheat for some reason
>I will now mix it in water for some reason

That's literally how you eat it though. That's the only way to eat it.
Furthermore, even if people weren't doing that with cereals they were already doing that with nuts, specifically Acorns. Acorn flour was a big deal to both Humans and Neanderthals. You're doing this thing where you think it isn't within people's mindset or wheelhouse to see a nut and say to themselves, "If I crack that open there's probably food innit."
Humans in general were, and still are, always just interested in finding more food, more ways to eat food, more ways to make food last. People were putting food into water and fermenting it or boiling it for ages.

> Now i will put this goop in the oven and place yeast on it

It's a process.
People didn't start 'yeasting' bread until well after caveman times. The first breading people all made flatbreads and unleavened breads: dough, water, maybe some salt, into the heat it goes. That's it.

>It seems unintuitive to invent

You should look into the introduction of corn into sub-Saharan Africans. They spent most of their lives never touching crops, but they got introduced to corn and now finally they could grow something in their dry, unbearably hot, territory, and suddenly you start seeing them behave in the same ways other people did before them. They make it into porridges, flatbreads, little dumplings, mix it with milk and ferment it, etc.

com:
>“Cavalry is useful before, during, and after the battle.”
The uses of cavalry were threefold: reconnaissance and screening during the advance to battle, shock and mobility in combat, and exploitation and punishment against a defeated enemy.

>“Without cavalry, battles are without result.”
Most importantly, as he understood it, cavalry was the arm that allowed for decisive victory, because it was the cavalry that would run down and exploit a compromised enemy army. Without a strong cavalry force, a defeated enemy could simply withdraw from the field. While cannon and musket killed the most men during the set piece phase of the battle, it was cavalry that inflicted terrible damage once the defeated army broke and attempted to flee.

https://bigserge.substack.com/p/napoleons-art-of-warfare

Three particular ingredients were crucial for granting Napoleon’s army its characteristic speed.

1. The Corps System: The organization of Napoleon’s army into self-sufficient combined arms corps allowed the army to disperse and travel on independent lines of advance. This made the army both faster, by distributing it on many different roads, and more ambiguous by disguising its intentions.

2. The Officers: By dispersing his corps, Napoleon also by definition dispersed his command system. [...] This was a monumental step towards a recognizably modern command and control system and professional officer corps. At the apex of this system were Napoleon’s famed Marshals.

3. The roads and towns of Europe: The Grande Armee was able to move at great speed thanks to the density of the roads and settlements throughout Europe. The road system allowed for not only the rapid travel of the main bodies of men, but also communication between the dispersed units via messengers on horseback. Furthermore, the population density allowed the army to move without supply chains by requisitioning food from local civilians as they passed through.

-
